title: French Cr√™pes Recipe
description: These French cr√™pes are thin, delicate, and delicious for breakfast or dessert. Fill as you like with fresh berries, jam, or chocolate spread.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Breakfast and Brunch Crepes Sweet French Cr√™pes 4.6 (763) 555 Reviews 150 Photos French cr√™pes are good for weekend breakfasts, or even for desserts. Serve rolled up and filled with jam or fruit and whipped cream. Submitted by CYBERCHEF Updated on April 25, 2025 Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 150 150 150 150 Prep Time: 5 mins Cook Time: 25 mins Total Time: 30 mins Servings: 12 Yield: 12 cr√™pes Jump to Nutrition Facts Jump to recipe These French cr√™pes are soft, tender, and paper thin. They taste just like they came from a fancy French restaurant! French Cr√™pe Ingredients These are the simple ingredients you‚Äôll need to make this classic French cr√™pe recipe: Flour: These French cr√™pes start with all-purpose flour, which gives them structure.¬†Sugar: Subtly sweeten the cr√™pes with a teaspoon of white sugar.¬†Salt: A pinch of salt enhances the overall flavor.Eggs: Eggs add moisture and bind the batter together.Milk and butter: Milk and melted lend more moisture and keep the cr√™pes tender. How to Make French Cr√™pes You‚Äôll find the full, step-by-step recipe below ‚Äî but here‚Äôs a brief overview of what you can expect when you make homemade French cr√™pes: Sift the dry ingredients together in one bowl and beat the eggs and milk in another.¬†Beat the dry mixture into the wet mixture, then stir in the melted butter.¬†Pour or scoop the batter into a greased griddle or frying pan.¬†Rotate the skillet to spread batter out in a thin layer.¬†Cook until the top of the cr√™pe is no longer wet and the bottom is light brown.Flip and cook until the cr√™pe is lightly browned on both sides.¬† How to Serve French Cr√™pes Top or fill the French cr√™pes however you like. Popular choices include whipped cream, fresh fruit, fruit sauce, cream cheese, and chocolate-hazelnut spread. You can also make savory cr√™pes with cheese, meats, and/or veggies. How to Store French Cr√™pes Stack the French cr√™pes with wax paper in between each layer, then place them in an airtight container or zip-top bag. Store in the refrigerator for up to two days or freeze for up to two months. Allrecipes Community Tips and Praise ‚ÄúCooked to perfection,‚Äù raves Stephen Ormsby. ‚ÄúA little bit of batter goes a long way and makes a fluffy crepe ready for filling.‚Äù ‚ÄúThese were awesome,‚Äù says diana alanis. ‚ÄúFirst time making cr√™pes and my kids loved them with Nutella. Super easy to make if you follow the directions. I did add one more tbsp of sugar and some vanilla extract. I have made them three times this week.‚Äù ‚ÄúGreat recipe,‚Äù according to Miranda Hooker Alt. ‚ÄúIt took a couple tries before I got the right shape for my cr√™pes, but they had a great texture and flavor. I‚Äôll definitely be making these again. Huge hit for Easter brunch!‚Äù Editorial contributions by Corey Williams Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 12 servings 1 cup all-purpose flour 1 teaspoon white sugar ¬º teaspoon salt 3 eggs 2 cups milk 2 tablespoons butter, melted Directions Gather all ingredients. Jen Causey / Food Stylist: Jennifer Wendorf / Prop Stylist: Christina Daley Sift flour, sugar, and salt into a bowl; set aside. Beat eggs and milk together in a large bowl with an electric mixer. Jen Causey / Food Stylist: Jennifer Wendorf / Prop Stylist: Christina Daley Beat in flour mixture until smooth; stir in melted butter. Jen Causey / Food Stylist: Jennifer Wendorf / Prop Stylist: Christina Daley Lightly grease a griddle or frying pan; heat over medium-high heat. Pour or scoop the batter onto the griddle, using approximately 2 tablespoons for each cr√™pe. Jen Causey / Food Stylist: Jennifer Wendorf / Prop Stylist: Christina Daley Immediately rotate the skillet to spread batter out in a thin layer. Cook until the top of the cr√™pe is no longer wet and the bottom has turned light brown, 1 to 2 minutes. Jen Causey / Food Stylist: Jennifer Wendorf / Prop Stylist: Christina Daley Shake the pan or loosen with a spatula; turn or flip it over and cook until other side has turned light brown, about 1 minute more. Repeat with remaining batter. Jen Causey / Food Stylist: Jennifer Wendorf / Prop Stylist: Christina Daley Serve with your choice of fillings or toppings, and enjoy! Jen Causey / Food Stylist: Jennifer Wendorf / Prop Stylist: Christina Daley I Made It Print 1,447 home cooks made it! Nutrition Facts (per serving) 94 Calories 4g Fat 10g Carbs 4g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 12 Calories 94 % Daily Value * Total Fat 4g 5% Saturated Fat 2g 11% Cholesterol 55mg 18% Sodium 97mg 4% Total Carbohydrate 10g 4% Dietary Fiber 0g 1% Total Sugars 2g Protein 4g 8% Vitamin C 0mg 0% Calcium 56mg 4% Iron 1mg 4% Potassium 90mg 2% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. (-) Information is not currently available for this nutrient. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of French Cr√™pes 01 of 150 Photo by¬† Jen Causey / Food Stylist: Jennifer Wendorf / Prop Stylist: Christina Daley 02 of 150 Photo by¬† FizzyHam5825 05/12/2024 A keeper! Easy to follow Easy simple delicious recipe!‚ù§Ô∏è 03 of 150 Photo by¬† SpeedyAhi4988 02/24/2024 Easy to follow Worth the effort Great flavors This recipe brought back memories of living in Montreal Canada. Thank you. 04 of 150 Photo by¬† Deborah Smith 06/03/2023 Very light and nice. I have made these a hundred times and they are always the way I like them. Crepes I like are not sweet (this has a bit of sugar, does not make them sweet) but the toppings are what makes them stand out as sweet or savory. Make sure you cook the first side until brown edges, then flip. Use 1/4 c to scoop out batter and you will have 12 crepes. Love this recipe. 05 of 150 Photo by¬† Silvia 09/04/2022 Love it and totally recommend it. Delicious and less greasy. This is a keeper. Nutella in the inside and for decoration and lots of fruit(it feels like I‚Äôm eating healthy). Thank you so much.üíï 06 of 150 Photo by¬† SassyGum5792 07/05/2022 Love it ‚ù§Ô∏è very simple. I used 2 non-stick pans to save time and didn't use any extra oil as butter was mixed in ingredients. Medium heat was perfect. I used 1/4 cup for each crepe and quickly angle the frying pan to have the flower mix spreading and even out the whole pan. Photo was my French crepes breakfast, filled with fresh picked strawberries, homemade strawberries jam/syrup and PC chocolate syrup. YUMMY 07 of 150 Photo by¬† Bob King 03/08/2022 I have made these twice. The first time, I piped sweet whipped cream into and onto them. The second time I filled them with buttery Carrboro rice and long grain white rice together and served on top of Philadelphia cream cheese and a bit of Smucker's marmalade to make a somewhat sweet, somewhat savory treat. 08 of 150 Photo by¬† Jaz 09/11/2021 09 of 150 Photo by¬† thalia 01/10/2021 10 of 150 Photo by¬† Evangelia 09/20/2020 1 2 3 4 5 Next You‚Äôll Also Love Basic Cr√™pes 4,329 Ratings Cr√™pes Suzette 2 Ratings Regular Cr√™pes 113 Ratings Cr√™pes 1,209 Ratings Dessert Crepes 1,207 Ratings Chocolate Banana Crepes 21 Ratings Love Letter - Crepes 3 Ratings Egg-White Crepes 102 Ratings Breakfast Crepes 201 Ratings Chocolate Crepes 30 Ratings Real French Cr√™pes 138 Ratings 17 Dessert Crepe Recipes Cr√™pes Suzette 5 Ratings Eggless Cr√™pes 58 Ratings Grandma Irena's Palacsinta (Hungarian Crepes) 23 Ratings Palacinky 5 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices ¬† Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith¬†publishing¬†family.
